title: Big Creek Lodge
description:
Located in the community of Edwardsburg and built in 1934, the Big Creek Lodge and nearby amenities provided a place for backcountry recreationists, miners, and travelers a place to stop and rest on their way into the heart of the Idaho wilderness. 
The original Big Creek Lodge and gas station burned in a localized fire in October of 2008, leaving behind the general store/post office, a historic tack shed, and a duplex cabin. In 2018, a rebuilt Big Creek Lodge opened to the public, providing once more a place for backcountry pilots and recreationists to stay and eat.
location: Edwardsburg, ID; Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 1680.0191 Big Creek Payette NF 1950s (2).tif

title: Big Creek Lodge
description: Big Creek Lodge, in the mid-1900s, provided a place where anyone could stop in for good conversation and a cool drink. In such a remote area, one which often required a combination of sled dogs, snowshoes, and airplanes to reach in the wintertime, folks valued being able to find community and a warm place to rest. The new lodge, opened to the public in 2018 after the original burned in October of 2008, stands near the historic structures that survived the flames.
location: Edwardsburg, ID; Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 66-74-57 Big Creek.jpg

title: Goat Mountain in Payette National Forest
description: The historical photograph calls this impressive peak "Mt. Napier". In 1904, William and Annie Edwards established Edwardsburg and their son, Napier, grew to be a notorious character along the drainage. If some once called this peak "Mt. Napier", the name didn't stick and it is now widely known as Goat Mountain.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 2310.0068 Goat Mountain (_Mt.Napier_) From Big Creek Station Idaho NF#85E0.tif

title: Big Creek Ranger Station
description:
The use of stock, horses and mules, has always been a significant feature of the Idaho backcountry and wilderness. In the comparison of these two images, one may think the Big Creek Forest Service Work Station doesn't have the stock it used to, but the camera doesn’t capture everything. Most of the animals are outside the frame of the photograph and the corral is now located behind the commissary, the building on the left hand side of the photograph. 
Riding in the backcountry with stock is difficult now, as the less-traveled trails become more choked with deadfall from the Clear Creek Complex fire that ripped through the Big Creek area in July and August of 2000.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 2300.0188_Big Creek Ranger Station_spring 1955_Dutch the Palomino FLIP.jpg

title: View of McFadden Mountain
description:
The Big Creek airstrip is north of Edwardsburg and just up the road from the Big Creek Lodge. This area hasn't experienced significant wildfire for approximately 100 years. Evident in these photographs are consistent dense stands of conifers on the hogback to the viewers right of the airstrip, and on McFadden Mountain in the background. 
One change is the removal of fencing along the airstrip. Originally used to keep stock and elk herds off of the runway, its absence speaks to changes both in elk populations and methods of backcountry access.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 2300.0068_McFadden Mtn_from Big Creek Ranger Station (spring 1955).jpg

title: The Big Creek/Smith Creek trailhead
description: In 1955, the Frank Church⎼River of No Return Wilderness was still the Idaho Primitive Area. In the historic photograph, the forked road is almost as impacted going to the right as it is to the left, since at this time folks could drive down the Big Creek trail (to the right) as far as Crooked Creek, about 12 miles. Of course now, as designated wilderness, use of all motorized equipment is prohibited, and traveling into Big Creek through the trailhead is either on stock or your own feet. In the contemporary photograph, the Wilderness boundary is a few yards off to the right of the frame, and the road traveling left continues up Smith Creek.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: 2300.0159_Don Wilson_at entrance to Primitive area_Smith Creek_1955.jpg

title: View of McFadden Mountain from the southern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description: The Big Creek airstrip has been in use for almost 100 years and is a key landmark of the Frank Church⎼River of No Return Wilderness. Located on the western boundary of the Frank Church Wilderness, it serves as a major stopping point for aviators going further into the Idaho backcountry. Today, it isn't abnormal to see a dozen airplanes or more at the top of the Big Creek airstrip, especially if it’s a Sunday and the Big Creek Lodge is serving their famous breakfast special.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_11.jpg

title: View of McFadden Mountain from the southern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description:
When Senator Frank Church was proposing for 2.3 million acres of Idaho's wilderness to be protected, he sought out support from one of the backcountry's biggest stakeholder groups: aviators. Senator Frank Church compromised with the aviation community to ensure the entirety of the proposed area was protected, while still giving the opportunity for pilots and recreationists to access the backcountry airstrips that had been established and used in the wilderness area prior to its designation. 

This is one reason why the Frank Church Wilderness is so unique: within the wilderness boundaries, one cannot ride a bike, run a chainsaw, or even use a wheelbarrow; but you can fly in on a plane and land at any of the public access airstrips.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_1.jpg

title: View of McFadden Mountain from the southern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description:
One of the biggest changes to the Big Creek airstrip has been the amount of use it gets. Today, the amount of people flying into the Frank Church⎼River of No Return Wilderness exceeds the numbers of the past. Whether stakeholders view this is a negative or a positive change is dependent on their personal values and experiences. 
Some folks who have spent decades in Big Creek remark on the noise pollution and how the increased number of planes overhead has affected their experience in the wilderness. Others realize that landing a plane along Big Creek is no easy task, and fear for those flying into the Idaho backcountry without the necessary skills and experience. And some remember when casting your fly rod at Cabin Creek meant you had spent hours on the trail to get there in the first place.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_12.jpg

title: View of McFadden Mountain from the southern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description: A notable lack of change can be seen in the coniferous vegetation in both photographs. This speaks to the absence of fire in this area, and has elicited some concern for the airstrip, the Big Creek Forest Service Work Station, and the inhabitants of the Edwardsburg community.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_13.jpg

title: View of Goat Mountain from the northern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description: In the 1940's, significant drainage improvements were made to the airstrip. McCorkel Creek, running parallel to the runway on its eastern side, was quite popular with beavers, and their activity would repeatedly flood the airstrip.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_2.jpg

title: View of Goat Mountain from the northern end of the Big Creek Airstrip
description: This repeat photograph pair shows a different view of the Big Creek airstrip, looking to the south, as if the photograph was taken as the plane was landing on the runway. As a plane approaches the top of the airstrip, the pilot and passengers can appreciate Goat Mountain, a thick carpet of green forest, and think of how soon they’ll get to walk into the Big Creek Lodge for a hot breakfast or a cool drink.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: AERO_00135_5.jpg

title: Big Creek Forest Service Work Station
description:
Goat Mountain provides an impressive backdrop to the road leading to the Big Creek Forest Service Work Station, located to the right. The Forest Service has always had a strong presence in Big Creek and the surrounding area. Built in 1924, the station operated in the Big Creek Ranger District and was positioned on the Western border of the Idaho Primitive Area. 

The Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness was established in 1980, combining the Idaho Primitive Area, the Salmon River Breaks Primitive Area, and a portion of the Magruder Corridor. In 1984, Big Creek Ranger District was combined with the pre-existing Krassel Ranger District, and the Big Creek Forest Service Work Station now operates in Payette National Forest.
location: Payette National Forest, ID
filename_old: Big Creek Admin Site ca 1952 - Bob Dustman Collection (1).PNG

title: View of Monumental Bridge at the confluence of Big Creek and Crooked Creek
description:
In 1953, the painter on Monumental Bridge was in the Idaho Primitive Area and most likely accessed his workstation by vehicle, traveling along Big Creek down from the trailhead at Smith Creek. The bridge is a standing symbol of the amount of traffic this area in particular used to see, especially from mining operations, prospecting, ranching and outfitting. 

Monumental Bridge is just upstream from the mouth of Monumental Creek, a long drainage meandering south Crooked Creek empties into Big Creek at Monumental Bridge. Traveling up the Crooked Creek drainage leads towards two other Forest Service Ranger Stations, Cold Meadows and Chamberlain Basin.
location: Big Creek; Crooked Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Monumental Bridge - ca1953 - Bob Dustman Collection (1).PNG

title: Monument on Monumental Creek
description: This interesting geological formation is right off the trail as one travels down Monumental Creek.
location: Monumental Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2800.0003 Monument On Monumental Creek Payette NF 1948.tif

title: Monument on Monumental Creek
description: This monument may have been historically significant to the Tukudeka, or Sheepeater Indians, though not much information is publicly known. Named for what it is on US Forest Service topographic maps, there is some evidence to suggest that the formation had some colorful and imaginative monikers in the past. During the gold rush era, miners and prospectors traveled along Monumental Creek frequently.
location: Monumental Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 4390.0001 (363445) Idaho NF Monument on Monumental Creek 1936 or 1937.tif

title: Coxey Hole
description: Noting the senesced vegetation in the historical photograph, the contemporary one precedes it by a month or so. This accounts for the greener vegetation and slightly higher water levels. Some changes to note are the conifers and snags in the contemporary photograph, as well as sediment loading in the creek bottom. A significant wildfire, such as the one which burned through this drainage in 2000, can increase erosion, moving soil down the unstable sides of the canyon and into the river.
location: Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0193_Coxey Hole_Big Creek_1955 or 1956.jpg

title: Crescent Meadows
description:
The trail leading into Crescent Meadows loops west to the Snowshoe Mine and then back down Crooked Creek to its confluence with Big Creek, near the Monumental Bridge. Crescent Meadows saw much more activity than it does today, what with an operating mine nearby and abundant elk moving through the area. In the historical photograph, a member of a hunting party, Homer Martin, stands in front of an open meadow that was most likely grazed and browsed upon by domestic stock and cattle, as well as ungulates such as elk. 

After the Clear Creek Complex fire in 2000, the willows in Crescent Meadows rebounded heartily and filled the meadows in thick clumps. The hillsides, once covered with conifers, are much the opposite, with only sparse mosaic patterns of trees spared from the flames. This photograph pair demonstrates how fire initiated the cycle of succession in the meadow and on the hillsides.
location: Crescent Meadows; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0261_Crescent Meadows_Big Game Trip_Homer Martin_1945 (2).jpg

title: Crescent Meadows
description: In the historical photograph, Dan LeVan, a Forest Service ranger with the Big Creek Ranger District, sits on his mule during a big game hunting trip in 1945. Hunting
location: Crescent Meadows; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0261_Crescent Meadows_Big Game Trip_Dan LeVan_1945 (5).jpg

title: Crescent Meadows
description: pack string
location: Crescent Meadows; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0261_Crescent Meadows_Big Game Trip_Big Creek Ranger District_1945 (10).jpg

title: Crescent Meadows
description: Two members of a hunting party eat lunch in Crescent Meadows. The ground they are standing on looks relatively grazed of its grasses; this in turn increases the shrub component, as one can see with the presence of sagebrush in the historical photograph. Whether or not a rancher was grazing cattle in Crescent Meadows in the 1940s is not readily identifiable, but elk graze similarly to cattle, rather than just browsing as deer do. Though there lies some contention about whether elk were historically characteristic of the Big Creek area, their population did begin to increase near 1950. It is possible the grasses and forbs that would be covering the ground in 1945 were grazed upon by elk. The elk population in Big Creek has been declining, which means fewer sagebrush and more grasses and forbs in Crescent Meadows, as can be seen in the contemporary photograph.
location: Crescent Meadows; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0261_Crescent Meadows_Big Game Hunt Trip_Farrel & Martin eating lunch (7).jpg

title: Acorn Creek
description: Shrubs and bushes have overgrown the property where Dewey Moore's ranch was on Acorn Creek. They do not, however, hide the buildings that are seen in the historical photograph. Those structures were burned by the US Forest Service during a period of wilderness reclamation, immediately preceding Wilderness designation of the area in the mid-1970s. Signs of human habitation that couldn't be burned, such as machinery,  were buried. What remains of Dewey Moore's ranch is a short airstrip that is still used by backcountry aviation enthusiasts and recreationists, as well as signs of past habitation, including a diverted creek and clumps of rhubarb that have long escaped the garden.
location: Acorn Creek; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: MA 2011-03 Wallace Family Records 08- UI Special Collections.jpg

title: The cave at the mouth of Cave Creek
description: A rider and their horse stop near the footbridge that crosses the mouth of Cave Creek, which flows into Big Creek. The impressive cave looms above them. The cave stays relatively constant throughout the years, looking out at coniferous and riparian vegetation that shift and change with the seasons.
location: Cave Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0143_Cave Creek_Mouth of Cave Creek_1955.jpg

title: Looking west at Big Creek and Cabin Creek meadows
description: This view is of the Cabin Creek meadows. Taken above the Big Creek trail that skirts the meadows, looking to the west, Big Creek can be seen on the left hand side of the frame; Cabin Creek flows into Big Creek from the right of the frame. Following Cabin Creek upstream leads to open, livable space. After the Homestead Act of 1862, white settlers began to move into the Big Creek area. Cabin Creek was of particular interest due to the presence of the open meadows in an otherwise steep and rocky drainage. From that point onward, Cabin Creek was home to squatters, settlers, homesteaders, farmers and ranchers during the pre- and post- WWII era, dude ranchers, and outfitters.
location: Cabin Creek; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 09.jpg

title: Looking east at Big Creek and the Cabin Creek meadows
description:
The large meadow in these photographs was hayed during much of the time Cabin Creek was occupied by year-round and part-time residents, up until this land was designated wilderness in 1980. Of note is a particular change to the riparian vegetation. In 1955, there were more willow stands in the meadow and the cottonwood grove seen in the contemporary photograph was not present. 

Big Creek has braided and re-channelized, shifting position with the assistance of human and natural forces in the past 60 years. Some differences are due to channelization with the intent of creating more hay pasture; the fire in 2000 also played a role, moving more sediment into the riverbed and along the banks. 

Some changes cannot be captured in a repeat photograph, such as what the rest of Big Creek looks like in this meadow area, or what wildlife are or are not present. Moose were frequently seen in Cabin Creek meadows but their population declined after the big fire of 2000. The fire should have stimulated food for the moose, as it did in Crescent Meadows where the willows exploded in numbers. Initially, however, the moose were at a disadvantage with little food and little cover after the fires, and so were vulnerable to starvation, and to predation by wolves and mountain lions.
location: Cabin Creek; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0150_Hay Meadows at Cabin Creek_Ervin Bobo_ 1955.jpg

title: Cabin Creek looking north
description:
The ungulate populations along the Big Creek drainage and Cabin Creek have changed over time, such as with moose, elk, and mule deer. Cabin Creek was once a place to spot large herds of elk, but numbers have dwindled significantly in the past 20 years. Some folks will attribute this population decline to the introduction of wolves, while others will argue elk weren’t historically a part of that landscape. Others might see the wildfire of 2000 to blame for pushing elk out of the area.

Cabin Creek is a popular location for outfitting. This change to elk populations has not only impacted success during hunting trips but has also altered the amount of traffic Cabin Creek sees during the late summer and fall. It is hard to make a living taking customers on a elk hunting trip when it is hard to find elk, and the terrain is difficult to traverse due to the steep slopes and downed, blackened snags. Many outfitters couldn’t do it anymore, but there are still some who tough it out and make it work, because elk or no elk, Big Creek, Cabin Creek… this area is home to them.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0236_Winter Range on Cabin Creek D-8_1954 (2 of 3).jpg

title: Small cabin built by Bill Wallace at Cabin Creek, restored
description:
Most of the structures built at Cabin Creek no longer exist. In the mid- to late-1970s, the US Forest Service went through the Big Creek drainage and reclaimed much of the land. During the process of reclamation, the US Forest Service purchased most of the private holdings in the drainage and burned, buried, and/or removed most of the structures and equipment. 

The process of wilderness reclamation along Big Creek, and especially at Cabin Creek, finds multiple perspectives and parties at a crossroad of opinions and values. At the time of reclamation in 1975, most of the structures at Cabin Creek were only around 30 years old, and weren’t old enough to be categorized as historically significant. To burn and remove these structures was consistent with Wilderness Act regulations and intents, and purist wilderness philosophy.

Others think of the historical and cultural significance these original cabins could have had, had they been kept in the area. Only two buildings from the original Wallace homestead on Cabin Creek were kept and restored: one was dismantled and transferred to University of Idaho's Taylor Wilderness Research Station, and the other is seen in this photograph here. Restoration efforts of this cabin have retained its original structure, and the cabin still has the "Flying W" brand in the log to the left of the door, a reference to the Merl and Jean Wallace ranch property.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0538_Cabin Creek_Cabin Protection_Clem Pope_(ca 1993) (3).jpg

title: Mouth of Spring Creek
description:
Located across from Cabin Creek and at the mouth of Spring Creek, this "ranch" was occupied by the Caswells from 1898 to 1906. The Caswells then sold the cabin and property to the Conyers. The main cabin in the center of the historical photograph was later dismantled and moved further up Cabin Creek to the Wallace homestead in 1933. 

Rex Lanham moved in after purchasing the Wallace ranch, and the cabin stayed on their homestead until the US Forest Service purchased the Lanham ranch during wilderness reclamation in the mid-1970s. Over 100 years later, the cabin is now used during the field season to house the US Forest Service trail crew. All else from this original site, however, no longer exists. To some folks who used to visit or live in Cabin Creek before 1980, these are the pieces of history missing from the current visual narrative of Cabin Creek.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: UI Special Archives Cougar Dave Lewis Papers- MG 190003_ Bellingham place - above Cabin Cr. 1918 or after..jpg

title: Looking towards the Cabin Creek airstrip
description:
Located behind the equipment shed in the historical photograph is the lower airstrip at Cabin Creek. For its position on the landscape, only the top of it can be seen in the contemporary photograph. The lower airstrip is a key feature of the Cabin Creek area; most of the flights that land at Cabin Creek now are for recreation, with hunters, fishermen, backcountry aviators, and other recreationists flying into the backcountry for a wilderness experience. This is a marked contrast to when dude ranchers like Rex Lahnam occupied Cabin Creek, and would often fly in food, materials, equipment and supplies to their ranch.

This photograph pair gives a stark visual of the decision to fully reclaim the wilderness before its designation in 1980. The structures and equipment at the Lanham Ranch and other parts of Cabin Creek are now gone, to provide an authentic wilderness experience or to erase the history of the area⎼it depends on who you talk to.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0243_Cabin Creek Ranch_Equipment shed and Tractor_unknown date.jpg

title: The upper airstrip at Cabin Creek
description: A defining characteristic of Cabin Creek which hasn't changed much is aviation. The historical photograph shows the first plane to fly out of Cabin Creek in 1931, to evacuate Noel Routson who had been injured by falling rock. He was carried on a litter twelve miles from the site of injury to Cabin Creek, and then flown out. This original airstrip is on a rise just north of the airstrip that is heavily used now.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0185 Airplane @ Cabin Creek That Flew Noel Routson Out Idaho NF 1931.tif

title: View of Horse Mountain from Garden Ranch Flat
description:
Horse Mountain is a tall peak on the north side of Big Creek across from Taylor Wilderness Research Station, and is visible in the center of the photographs. Note the presence of telephone poles in the historical photograph; Garden Ranch is named for the folks who homesteaded in that area. The homestead site originally extended north and south on both sides of Big Creek, and cultural sites from the homestead, as well as from the Tukudeka, are present in the area. 

The Tukudeka, or Sheepeater Indians, are a band of the Northern Shoshone; they are members of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes at Fort Hall Reservation of Idaho.  Their traditional homelands include the vast landscape in and surrounding the Big Creek and Salmon River drainages. Homesteaders, such as the ones who settled Garden Ranch, were breaking ground in soil that was already heavily rooted with human history and culture.
location: Garden Ranch Flat; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Garden Ranch Flat 1930s (J. Bayok - Holm Collection) (1).jpg

title: Cabin Creek
description: The CAT tractor, or bulldozer, in the historical photograph has a funny place in folks' memories of wilderness reclamation. A large piece of equipment, it couldn't be burned or flown out, and it would be too damaging to walk it out of the drainage at any time of year. So, after having sat unused for some years, US Forest Service employees got it up and running again, used it to dig a large hole... and then the CAT buried itself. There is most likely another bulldozer buried along the Big Creek drainage, along with other tools and equipment.
location: Cabin Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Cabin Creek_1971_USFS.jpg

title: The cave at the mouth of Cave Creek
description: Repeat photographs of the large Cave at the mouth of Cave Creek. The historical photograph was taken during Jim and Holly Akensons first term as managers of the Taylor Ranch, now referred to as the Taylor Wilderness Research Station. The footbridge, which crosses Cave Creek, is more overgrown in the contemporary photograph; the great fire of 2000 shows it's mark on the right-hand side of the frame, where the thick stand of evergreens thins to snags.
location: Cave Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Ed Krumpe Collection Taylor Ranch Old Pics. Cave at Cave Creek.tif

title: The Vines airstrip area
description: This repeat photograph pair is a good example of what happens when the contemporary photographer doesn't have the same resources as the original photographer. After much scurrying around, the conclusion was that the historical photograph must have been taken from a plane, as it was virtually impossible to get the same height and location, or it was taken from a tree that is no longer standing. Therefore: the imperfect repeat photograph. Both photos do however show the Vines airstrip area. The airstrip is on the south side of Big Creek, on the opposite side of the trail, and landing at it is quite technical. John Vines was the man who settled in this spot, which is in the Garden Creek area. The rock outcropping that can be seen in the Garden Ranch Flat photograph pair is in the center of the photos here.
location: Vines Airstrip; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1-J. Bayok - Holm Collection - Vines 1930s 2.jpg

title: Looking east from the Rush Point Lookout Trail
description: The Rush Point Lookout Trail leads from the Rush Creek drainage, on the western side of Taylor Wilderness Research Station, up to the Rush Point Lookout. The lookout was active for a while, but has since been decommissioned. In the historical photograph, a summer intern with Taylor Wilderness Research Station, Tammi Lesh, and the mule Mia, stand in front of a spectacular view. Looking to the east, one can follow Big Creek downstream to its confluence with the Middle Fork of the Salmon River. The peaks in the distance are the great Bighorn Crags, which make the formidable eastern border of the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness. Note the vegetation changes in the distance from wildfire.
location: Rush Point Lookout Trail; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Tammi Lesh- summer interns & Mia Looking East. Rush Pt. LO. 1987.jpg

title: The Lewis Cabin at Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: In the historical photograph, US Forest Service forest supervisor Richard Rutledge throws a diamond hitch over a load which this horse will carry. This photo hangs in the cabin that is featured in it, which still exists as the Lewis Cabin at the Taylor Wilderness Research Station. The contents of the photograph are unique in a handful of ways, a couple of which are described. First, the reminder of the presence of stock in the Idaho backcountry, and the old methods, such as a diamond hitch. Secondly, since so many of the structures along Big Creek were burned prior to wilderness designation in 1980, structures like the Lewis Cabin allow parts of the past to continue to exist tangibly in the present.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Old Ways_taken in front of the Lewis Lodge_1932.tif

title: Looking north, at the Cliff Creek drainage across Big Creek, from the Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: These photographs look south from Taylor Wilderness Research Station to the Cliff Creek drainage and bighorn sheep lambing cliffs. Big Creek runs across the bottom of the photo where the conifers and riparian trees and shrubs grow along its banks. In the early 20th century, Taylor Wilderness Research Station was a property owned by Dave Lewis, also known as Cougar Dave. Dave Lewis is a prominent figure in the settler history of the Big Creek drainage. He came into the Big Creek drainage as a cavalryman during the 1879 Sheepeater Campaign, and returned the next year to claim the 65-acre homestead that became Taylor Wilderness Research Station. Dave Lewis worked for the Forest Service for a time, gaining a reputation for hunting and killing mountain lions and other predatory game, hence the moniker "Cougar Dave".
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Cougar Dave Lewis Papers- MG 190005.png

title: The Lewis Cabin at Taylor Wilderness Research Station, with the Cliff Creek drainage to the north
description: Big Creek and the Cliff Creek drainage are in view in these repeat photographs, as well as the Lewis Cabin. The Lewis Cabin has had some building and foundation restoration work done throughout the years, with the addition of the section behind the main cabin as well. In the early 20th century, Dave Lewis was living on his homestead here. While the fire pit in the contemporary photograph cannot be seen in the historical photo, it is historically significant. Around this fire pit, the conception of the Idaho Primitive Area was spawned, an action of land preservation that would eventually turn the area into the Frank Church⎼River of No Return Wilderness. For this to have happened on the Dave Lewis homestead holds significance for those who are connected with the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness through Taylor Wilderness Research Station.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Cougar Dave Lewis Papers- MG 190006 1896-1928.png

title: View of the Cliff Creek drainage north of Big Creek, from Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: A man with a mule standing in the field wouldn't be an odd sight 100 years after the historical photograph was taken. Taylor Wilderness Research Station used mules and horses into the last decade. The buck and rail fencing that surrounds the pasture still works to hold the stock that stops in carrying visitors, alumni, and friends.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Cougar Dave Lewis Papers- MG 190006 1896-1928 (1).png

title: View of the Lewis Cabin at Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The Dave Lewis cabin, at the time of his residence and now. The vegetation around the cabin has grown, especially the Douglas Fir trees behind it. The Douglas Fir growing on the viewers right of the cabin in the historic photograph grew to match the size of its partner, the tree growing now, slightly behind the cabin. However, it was cut down in recent years. The stump is visible in the contemporary photograph.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Cougar Dave Lewis Papers- MG 190002.pdf

title: View of the Lewis Cabin, Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The tall evergreens dwarf the Dave Lewis Cabin at Taylor Wilderness Research Station. The Pioneer Creek drainage extends to the south and Dave Lewis Peak is visible in the draw. The Pioneer Creek drainage burned in 2000, and the once undulating skyline is broken by thousands of thin gray snags.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 7300.0286 Dave Lewis Ranch Big Creek Payette NF 1950.tif

title: View of Taylor Wilderness Research Station from the north side of Big Creek
description: Tree growth marks the time that passes at Taylor Wilderness Research Station, along with the addition of buildings, scars from fire, and other structural modifications on the property.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0225_Taylor Ranch (1).jpg

title: Structures and cabins at Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The long log cabin seen in both photographs came from the Lanham development at Cabin Creek. In 1990, University of Idaho had the Idaho National Guard dismantle the building, and fly sections of the log walls downstream to Taylor Wilderness Research Station. It was restored as a classroom and a bunkhouse, and serves to provide historical context, scientific material, a library, and an intellectual gathering place to the many students and faculty who visit Taylor Wilderness Research Station. The other two structures, the DeVlieg cabin, and the cookhouse, were built after 2002.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Interns Cabin.jpg

title: View of the landing strip at Taylor Wilderness Research Station, with Big Creek on the northern side
description: Taken only two years after the Clear Creek Complex fire, the historical photograph shows a defined, burned landscape. Luckily the fire burned up the Pioneer Creek drainage and spared much of the riparian vegetation around Taylor Wilderness Research Station, but folks familiar with the drainage felt the desolate landscape would never recover from the firestorm. They mourned the loss of the verdant, lush landscape they had known before, though their acute awareness of their environment allowed them to also appreciate the changes that began to happen right away. Cougar and moose struggled to adjust to their altered territories; elk and wolves moved north towards the Chamberlain Basin; elk calved in the Jim Hill Mustard that exploded along Big Creek’s banks; growth and productivity increased in Big Creek and its tributaries; and riparian shrubs such as willow rebounded quickly.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Landing strip at the ranch_Big Creek.jpg

title: View of the landing strip at Taylor Wilderness Research Station, with Big Creek on the northern side
description: Taylor Wilderness Research Station is the most remote research station in the lower 48 contiguous United States. Because of its remoteness, the airstrip serves as a vital access point for transporting anything and everything the research station needs to operate and function: people, equipment, propane, building materials, food, research tools, mail, and other supplies. Taylor Wilderness Research Station would not be able to operate at its current capacity, nor would it be able to serve so many students, if it weren’t for access by plane.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0236_Taylor Landing Field on Big Creek_1954 (3 of 3).jpg

title: Lower hayfield on the Taylor Wilderness Research Station property
description: When using horses and mules to pack supplies and travel throughout the area was commonplace, the animals couldn't always be let out to roam and graze. Aside from the grasses available in their pastures, the stock was sustained by hay. Jess and Dorothy Taylor, shown in the historical photograph here, stand in front of a massive pile of cut hay in the lower pasture on Taylor Wilderness Research Station property, back when it was the Taylor Ranch. Driving mule teams to cut hay for the stock at Taylor Wilderness Research Station was a practice that persisted well into the second term of scientists and caretakers Jim and Holly Akenson.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0236_Jess Taylor Ranch_on Big Creek_1954 (1 of 3).jpg

title: View of Taylor Wilderness Research Station from the north side of Big Creek
description: Taylor Wilderness Research Station and the Dave Lewis Ranch, about 100 years apart in these repeat photographs. Changes are evident: new buildings, vegetation growth and decay, alterations in land use; however, the landscape remains remarkably continuous.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: TWRS.jpg

title: View of Taylor Wilderness Research Station from the north side of Big Creek
description:
In 1964, wildlife biologist Maurice Hornocker entered the Big Creek drainage of the Idaho Primitive Area to conduct a landmark study of cougars. Big Creek, speckled with outfitters, homesteaders, miners and ranchers, wasn't entirely a lonely place. Maurice Hornocker grew acquainted with folks along the drainage, especially Jess Taylor who owned the Taylor Ranch, where Hornocker would be based during much of his cougar research.

In 1966, Hornocker wrote to Taylor expressing having found a potential, "agreeable", purchaser for the 65-acre Taylor Ranch, continuing a topic of conversation the two had discussed prior. In 1970, the University of Idaho purchased the full property from Jess and Dorothy Taylor. This acquisition, justified by Aldo Leopold's value for "land laboratories", filled a growing desire within the University of Idaho to focus on interdisciplinary research in wilderness environments.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0174_Jess Taylor Ranch_1955.jpg

title: View of Taylor Wilderness Research Station from the north side of Big Creek
description: From a distance, the view of the Taylor Wilderness Research Station, known as the Taylor Ranch in 1955, doesn't look much changed apart from shifts in vegetation, signs of fire, and some structural additions.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0161_Jess Taylor Ranch on Big Creek_1955.jpg

title: Looking west from the north side of Big Creek across from Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The Big Creek trail has shifted over time, as being built on the steep walls of a drainage presents challenges. Here, a forester with the US Forest Service sits on an original Big Creek trail line, located just a handful of meters above Big Creek. Note the amount of erosion and lack of riparian vegetation. The trail now is situated uphill from that location, rising up and out of the Cliff Creek drainage to continue for a while before coming back down to the level of Big Creek. Shrubs, trees, and forbs have established themselves along the bank of Big Creek, though the earth is still loose and rocky.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 1680.0225_Taylor Ranch_Forester trail (2).jpg

title: View of Goat Basin, looking south across Big Creek
description: A small section of Goat Basin, located up and out of the Big Creek canyon, is shown in these repeat photographs. Looking south across Big Creek from Goat Basin gives a stark reminder of the impact the wildfire had on the area in 2000. Goat Basin is a popular meadow for hunters to set up camp in the fall, to cross Big Creek and access the airstrip at Soldier Bar. Recently, the invasive spotted knapweed has been encroaching more and more on the native bunchgrass in the meadow, coming either from the creek bottom or carried in hay that may have had weed seeds in it. Spotted knapweed can be prolific and damaging to the native flora in an ecosystem, and to see it establishing itself out of the heavily trafficked creek drainage is discouraging for wildlife officers and ecologists.
location: Goat Basin; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: 2300.0144_Goat Basin_1955.jpg

title: Looking east on the Big Creek trail, near the crossing to Soldier Bar airstrip
description:
Though there is no longer a Forest Service sign pointing out Soldier Bar and Eagan Point, the crossing, which goes across Big Creek and leads to a steep trail, is still heavily used by backcountry recreationists. Soldier Bar is an airstrip situated about 300 meters above Big Creek and is open for public use. At the top stands a large marble monument dedicated to Harry Eagan, a soldier who died during the Sheepeater Campaign. 

In 1879, a United States cavalry entered into the Big Creek drainage to forcefully remove the Tukudeka, or Sheepeater Indians. This event, known as the Sheepeater Campaign, was sparked by the death of five Chinese miners at Oro Grande. The Sheepeater Indians were accused without evidence of these murders. The cavalrymen, at odds with the rugged and steep terrain, struggled to succeed in their mission. Harry Eagan was the only casualty on the US Cavalry side of the bitter chase. Five months after the campaign began, they captured fifty-one Tukudeka and forcefully relocated them to Fort Hall Reservation in southern Idaho.
location: Soldier Bar; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: S - 3 Eagan Point Trail Sign Big Creek Payette NF 1972.tif

title: View of the Bighorn Crags and the Soldier Bar airstrip
description:
The entirety of this repeat photograph pair shows part of the traditional homeland of the Sheepeater Indians, including what is now known as the Soldier Bar airstrip, the Middle Fork of the Salmon River drainage, Big Creek drainage, and Bighorn Crags. A mosaic of fire scarIndigenous landscape perspectives value fire.  "And so they would look at the land after fires, or even use fire specifically to say, 'Okay, this is where we want to go. From the fires that we set these years we know it's going to be that these plants are ready for us to come over there and start managing.'" "And so you sort of start mapping out the year and how you're going to move across the land of a season to start to gather food. And so these sorts of pictures sort of make me think that way - very broadly - about how you plan out the year, and then specifically why you're going to plan it that way."
((SM))
fire scars, Indigenous perspectives on landscape use
location: Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Ed Krumpe Collection Taylor Ranch Old Pics. Bighorn Crags.jpg

title: Researchers on the "benches", on the northern side of Big Creek across from Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description:
In the historical photograph, Jim Wood and Terry Mauer from University of Idaho News Bureau film bighorn sheep for a documentary on Taylor Wilderness Research Station and the wildlife in the area. The wildlife populations and dynamics have shifted over time, since the mid- to late-1980s, but at that time, Taylor Wilderness Research Station was in a prime location for wildlife research and study. Groups of bighorn sheep dotted the steep drainage walls; herds of elk moved across the open benches and meadows; moose whispered through the many willows and cottonwoods; wolves ran along the banks of Big Creek, and cougars marked their territories. The Big Creek drainage was alive with predators and prey, offering an amazing chance to research the dynamics of different wildlife populations. 

Today, one can still observe the charismatic megafauna that call the area home: elk, bighorn sheep, mule deer, wolves, and cougars. In the contemporary photograph, University of Idaho professors Teresa Cohn, Ph.D., and Ruby Fulton, Ph.D., along with Yolonda Youngs, Ph.D. from Idaho State University, stand looking at the north-facing mountainside across Big Creek, which rushes below.
location: Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Jim Akenson collection- Jim Wood & Terry Mauer filming.tif

description: From a distance, the view of the Taylor Wilderness Research Station doesn't look much changed apart from shifts in vegetation, signs of fire, and some structural additions.

title: View of the hay barn at Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description:
In the historical photograph, Ray Arnold, with flight service Arnold Aviation, takes off from the airstrip at Taylor Wilderness Research Station. Ray, who delivered the mail to the research station for decades, is remarkably flying out west to east, opposite of the normal flight path from this particular airstrip. 

The hay barn seen in both photographs was built during the tenure of managers Jim and Holly Akenson. Advocates of what they might call "the old ways" or "old Idaho", Jim and Holly Akenson prioritized giving student interns the opportunities to immerse themselves in the living history of the Taylor Wilderness Research Station. They focused on the 65-acre Taylor Wilderness Research Station, cultivating within student interns and visitors a sense of place and a historical relationship with the landscape and former homestead. Jim and Holly Akenson drove mule teams, rode pack trains throughout the backcountry, taught student interns how to cut hay, reconstruct cabins, use old-fashioned mowing machines, drive wagons, and raise barns. Because of their efforts, many students and visitors left Taylor Wilderness Research Station with a strong connection to the human efforts and history on the land.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Jim Akenson collection- Arnold Av. Barn building 1985.jpg

title: View from the western end of the Taylor Wilderness Research Station airstrip
description: In the historical photograph, Holly Akenson, former manager and biologist at the Taylor Wilderness Research Station, mows hay along the airstrip with mules Rocky and Top. Today, the airstrip is mowed with a riding lawnmower, and there are no mules or mule teams at the research station.
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Jim Akenson Collection- Holly mowing hay along airstrip w Rocky & Top. 1988.jpg

title: Looking at the hayfield at Taylor Wilderness Research Station
description: The Idaho National Guard air division based some fifty guardsmen out of Taylor Wilderness Research Station in the summer of 1989, one year before Jim and Holly Akenson finished their first term as managers. That summer, Jim and Holly had the goal of salvaging a cabin built by Rex Lanham in the 1960s at Cabin Creek. Their original plan to dismantle it, float the logs down Big Creek, and then reassemble what they could quickly manifested into a much bigger operation. In 1990, Jim and Holly drove a mule team six miles upstream from Taylor Wilderness Research Station to Cabin Creek and loaded pieces of the cabin in a stoneboat, a large type of sled used for moving heavy items. The mule team pulled the stoneboat up to the Cabin Creek airstrip, where a Skycrane and a Chinook helicopter waited. The cabin was then flown to Taylor Wilderness Research Station to become the Jim Peek Lab (formerly Lanham Lab).
location: Taylor Wilderness Research Station; Big Creek; Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness, ID
filename_old: Jim Akenson Collection- Nat. Guard @ Taylor summer before cabin move - 1989.jpg
